 This is more or less my understanding. Most of the SIVs that are a big deal lately seem to be pretty much just a good old fashioned securitization SPE. The big difference I can see is that under the old off book SPE model, the originator had to structure the transaction so they retained no effective control over the off balance sheet assets. With SIVs, it seems like the originator/sponser is actually underwriting the SIV fund. So, they did away with SPE securitization schemes because in truth it was just a giant scam, and it has been replaced with SIVs, which are almost exactly the same, only the originators underwrite the fund, which means they are closely tied to it, but they are doing it all off balance sheet.....
 
 I just don't see how they get away with it, unless FASB has just not quite gotten around to updating their definitions. 
 
 As a side note...SIVs are a scame anyway, no matter what you call them and frankly the fact that the SEC has been letting securitization SPEs operate in one form or the other for so many years jsut shows how broken the system is. Their sole purpose is to take high yielding junk assets and then re-package them to sell to the public at a lower rate since the poor sap that is buying the "cleaned" debt does not realize that he is buying some crack whores mortgage.

 Well kinda. It really is a bank "backing" an entity (called the SIV) that sells short term bonds to finance long term debt such as mortgages and what not. So pretty much the the short term loans are used to give out mortgages. The purpose is to take advantage of the difference in interest rates. Now since the SIV is its own entity the banks don't feel they should put them on their books eventhough they control them and pretty much back them in the event of failure (but only back them about half way or less because no one has that kinda money). 
 
 And yes, not on the financials...just like SPEs.
